Text: Honoré Daumier (1808-1879) was a French painter, sculptor, and printmaker. He is known for his lithographs that critically depicted the tumultuous sociopolitical climate in France during the nineteenth century.

Label: Le Charivari
Text: Honoré Daumier made sketches and lithographs for Charles Philipon's political satirical journals, La Silhouette, La Caricature, and then Le Charivari. The latter was where this collection, the Album du Siège, was published in the series “Actualités” (News of the Day) between the years 1870-1871.

Honoré Daumier's criticism of the Franco-Prussian War is evident throughout his Album du Siège lithographs. His works offer a scathing indictment of the conflict, and the suffering it inflicted upon ordinary people. The series is a testament to Daumier's skill as a social commentator and artist, and remains a significant work of political satire to this day.

Daumier also focused on the suffering of civilians during the war, particularly the hunger and deprivation caused by the siege of Paris. The desperateness and hunger of Parisians was represented by a Crowned Paris eating rats.

Label: Crowned Paris
Text: Starvation and food scarcity even drove civilians to eat cats and dogs to survive: "Cut off from supplies from the countryside, the Parisians held out by eating dogs, cats, and even most of the animals in the Paris zoo. The trees on the Champs-Elysées and in parks were cut down and burned for fuel.” Therefore, Daumier targeted the corrupt and ineffectual government officials who were responsible for the war and its disastrous consequences.

Label: Prix
Text: The entire album was priced at 5 francs during publication, although curiously, this edition is missing its price tag.

Print: Le Bombardement. Qu’estce que c’est que ça, papa? C’est le dernier bouquet des feux du 15 août.
Text: Daumier is known for critically depicting the sociopolitical climate in France during the nineteenth century. Daumier empathized with Les Bons Bourgeois (the urban middle class). Daumier printed this lithograph in his Album du Siège, which depicts scenes of everyday life amidst the chaos of the Franco-Prussian war, the siege of Paris, and political satire aimed at the government and its leaders. France declared war on Prussia in July 1870, but was quickly defeated due to Prussia's superior military and tactics. The war had a devastating impact on French civilians, particularly those living in Paris, which was besieged for several months. Parisians' lives altered dramatically during the four month siege. During 23 nights of bombardement in January 1871, some 12,000 shells fell on Paris neighborhoods, killing about 400 people.
The lithograph portrays "The Bombardment," referencing the bombings of the Franco-Purssian War https://ehistory.osu.edu/articles/siege-paris-during-franco-prussian-war
The caption notes an exchange between a father and son, which translates to "What is that, dad?" The father replies, "It is the last of the fireworks of August 15."

However, the dialogue between the father and son reveals that these are not fireworks at all, but bombs falling on the city. The title's reference to a fireworks display on August 15th adds a layer of irony to the scene, remeniscent of Louis Napoleon’s decree of moving the national holiday from the original Bastille Day on July 14 to August 15, known as La Saint-Napoléon.
Daumier's use of irony in this lithograph offers a poignant critique of the disconnect between the ruling class and the suffering of ordinary people during wartime.

The complex nature of international relations is illuminated with this lithograph, especially between France and England during this period. A variety of sentiments and issues are alluded to with depictions of attire, symbols, and words.

Label: Caption
Text: “Laissez appuyer moâ sur le bras à vôs!”, translates to “Let me lean on your arm!” The response to this, “Fallait pas me laisser amputer,” translates to “Shouldn’t have let me amputate.”

Label: Question d'Orient
Text: This phrase translates to the “Eastern Question,” which is a reference to the declining stability of the Ottoman Empire. As internal attempts to reform the so-called “sick man of Europe” failed in the long-run, various European nations stood eagerly at the sides, ready to snatch up potential colonies.

Label: Albion
Text: “Albion” references the phrase “Perfidious Albion," which was a pejorative term that was frequently leveled at England due to their history of treachery and disloyalty. By the nineteenth century, the phrase became a common utterance whenever England and France had tense relations. In the context of the Franco-Prussian War, anti-English sentiments may have stemmed from the overwhelming English opinions that France instigated the war.

Label: Mars
Text: Classical imagery is abundant in Daumier’s other works. This character is Mars, the Roman god of war who is a recurring motif in Le Charivari, often symbolizing war threats. The trident completes the allegory to England, a symbol of the nation’s mastery of the seas.

This allegorical image exemplifies the suffering of the French during the Franco-Prussian War and the impact of the five-month siege on Paris, which caused a famine. France and the year 1871 is represented as the weeping, mother-like figure who expresses her desolation at the fate of her country.

Label: Caption
Text: “Épouvantée de l'héritage,” translates to “Dismayed by her legacy.”

1871 also marks the year that this print was published in the satirical magazine Le Charivari. It also is the year after Emperor Napoléon III was deposed when the French were defeated in the disastrous Battle of Sedan. This conflict opened up the path for Prussian forces to take Paris, leading to the siege

Label: France
Text: A grieving France is the central figure in this print. She covers her eyes, refusing to look at the sea of bodies that are scattered to the horizon line.

In "Moi, je suis ravitaillé!" from Album du Siège, Honoré Daumier offers a commentary on the selfishness and indifference of those in power during times of crisis. Daumier expresses the sentiment of the Les Bons Bourgeois (the urban middle class).

Label: Moi, je suis ravitaille!
Text: The caption translates to "Me, I am restocked! The rest do not matter to me.”

This smug official, surrounded by crates of food and drink, represents those in the French nobility class during the 19th century. The official's dismissive statement highlights the callousness and lack of empathy shown by those in positions of privilege and power, especially during times of war. Daumier's use of caricature and satire in this lithograph is particularly effective, as he highlights the absurdity of the official's attitude and draws attention to the suffering and starvation of the less fortunate while Paris was under siege.

Daumier's work serves as a powerful critique of war as a destructive and futile enterprise, and a reminder of the human cost of political conflicts. His sharp social commentary and biting satire offer a powerful voice for those who suffered during this dark period in French history.
